text: I think we could go to Moscow now to
hear a little bit more about what the
Kremlin has been saying about all this
Jonah Fischer is there for us and Jonah
the Kremlin condemning this they've
called an urgent meeting of the rather
hamstrung UN Security Council what is
going on reading between the lines are
they as angry as they're saying in
public as they are behind the scenes
well in public they're certainly very
angry we've heard from the Russian
ambassador United States this morning
talking about unspecified consequences
of the strikes in Syria vad Amir Putin
himself has put out a statement in the
last couple of hours calling the strikes
an act of aggression against a sovereign
state that would indulge the terrorists
who've been tormenting the Syrian people
for seven years and that the actions of
the United States further exacerbates
the humanitarian catastrophe in Syria
angry words but I think in private
behind closed doors I think the Russians
will be breathing something of a sigh of
relief of course the fear in the
build-up to these strikes taking place
had been that there might be some sort
of military contact between the United
States and Russia Russia of course has
forces on the ground it has a naval base
but it's been pretty clear from the
information coming out of the Ministry
of Defense here in Moscow this morning
that there was no contact between the
strike and and the Russian forces on the
ground indeed that the Russian anti
defense anti-missile system was not
engaged in any way against these
missiles that were coming in so those
fears that this strike might lead to an
escalation in tension between the US and
Russia and perhaps even pressure on
Russia to respond in a military way well
that's not come to pass
Jona it's interesting to get
clarification as to whether or not the
Russians did engage any of these
missiles
I wonder we know that in Britain there
was a poll out in the last few days that
said about a fifth of the British public
only a fifth supported military action
this was before the strike and around
four-fifths said they didn't want it to
happen
there is no appetite for it we know that
in the United States there are large
sections of the population who also have
no appetite for this I'm wondering um
how whether it's possible to
characterize the russian population in
terms of the way that President Putin
and the Kremlin is approaching this
crisis well I think you have to firstly
look at how it's being covered here and
how the build-up to it being covered has
played out on Russian television here
lots of people still get their
information from the TV here and the
story that they have been told over the
last week or so is there is the Russian
government line very much that this is
something that has been staged this is a
provocation and that it isn't as it's
being described by much of the West a
chemical attack that has been
perpetrated by the Assad government in
Syria so in that context I think you'll
find that many people as here still
hugely supportive of what of what the
Russian government's doing because they
have been fed over the last weeks or so
this repeated message that there is a
conspiracy against Russia to put Russia
in a bad place both in relation to
what's happening in Syria and also the
screep al poisoning of course in the in
the United Kingdom that this all falls
into that bigger picture of the West
being out to get Russia and I think in
that context of what people being told
that many people will be we
wholeheartedly behind the Russian
government position today
all right Jonah fish we'll leave it
there Jenna Fischer live for us in
